title-group.article-title: Poly(amide-imide)s obtained from 3,5-diamino-N-(thiazol-2-yl)-benzamide and dicarboxylic acids containing various amino acid units
title-group.subtitle: Production, characterization and morphological investigation

abstract.p: This study reports a green approach toward the synthesis of novel optically active poly(amide-imide)s (PAI)s bearing thiazole moiety, which was formed by the polycondensation reaction of 3,5-diamino-N-(thiazol-2-yl)benzamide and various diacids containing natural amino acids in molten tetrabutylammonium bromide. Diamine monomer was synthesized by the reduction of 3,5-dinitro-N-(thiazol-2-yl)benzamide in methanol using iron oxide hydroxide as a catalyst. This catalyst can rapidly reduce the sulfur and azo-containing aromatic nitro compounds to the corresponding amines in high yield by employing hydrazine hydrate as a hydrogen donor. Chiral diacid monomers were synthesized in high yield through the reaction of pyromellitic dianhydride and amino acids (l-isoluecine, S-valine, S-methionine, and l-phenylalanine) in acetic acid. The direct polymerization reactions of these monomers provided a series of new optically active PAIs with inherent viscosities in the range of 0.20–0.28 dL g−1. The obtained polymers were characterized by Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy, specific rotation measurements, and the representative of them by proton nuclear magnetic resonance and elemental analysis techniques.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
In recent years, polyimides (PIs) have become a major class of polymers that have found a wide range of uses as high performance materials in the electronics industry. 1 Aromatic PIs have distinguished properties, such as good thermal stabilities, physical and mechanical properties, chemical resistance, and excellent creep. 2,3 Although they are well recognized as a class of thermally stable engineering polymers, they generally have been hard to process due to their infusibility and poor solubility in organic solvents. To overcome these difficulties, several approaches have been investigated in an attempt to improve the solubility of PIs, and the most important of them are the preparation of copolymers such as poly(amide-imide)s (PAIs) and poly(amide-ester-imide)s. 4
–12 PAIs are the compounds with bulky groups into the polymer backbone or bulky pendant groups seem to be a good balance between thermostability and processability. PAIs are thermally stable and processable compounds which have attracted great attention in the recent past decades, due to their exclusive combination of toughness, lightness, and dimensional stability at high temperatures. 13
–16

Ionic liquids (ILs), which have been widely promoted as ‘green solvents’, are attracting much attention for their applications in many fields of chemistry and in industries, which is due to their chemical stability, thermal stability, low vapor pressure, excellent ability to dissolve organic compounds, salts, and metals, facile recyclabilities, high specific solvent abilities, and high ionic conductivity properties. 17 –19 ILs are also investigated as components of the polymeric matrixes (such as polymer gels), as templates for porous polymers, and as novel electrolytes for electrochemical polymerizations. Several environmentally benign procedures have been successfully developed to avoid or at least minimize the use of environmentally damaging solvents on a large-scale, especially those that are volatile and difficult to handle. ILs have recently gained recognition as possible environmentally safe in a wide variety of organic transformations. 20
–23 Over the last few years, ILs have been popularly used as solvents for organic synthesis, catalysis, and also been used as media for extraction processes. 24 –26 The synthesis of polymers in IL media is also of significant scientific interest. Direct polyamidation reaction in ILs is a recently developed method of polymerization. The polyamidations in the ILs proceed as one-pot pathway reaction and have the advantages of direct polycondensation. 27
–31

Synthesis of optically active polymers is an important field in the macromolecular science as they locate a wide variety of potential applications based on the chiral structure. 32 An important field of application is chiral recognition. 33
–36 This ability of chiral polymers has been utilized in various forms of catalytic and separation chemistry. They are not only fundamentally interesting, due to the rich and complex architecture of macromolecular chirality when compared with that of small molecules, but also technologically important, because their unique chiral arrays give rise to a number of potential and, in some cases, commercially implemented applications. 37 Polymers derived from amino acid containing monomers are one of the most important compounds due to the great potential applications such as biocompatible and optically active materials. 38

In this article, the authors report the synthesis and characterization of new optically active PAIs from the step-growth polymerization of 3,5-diamino-N-(thiazol-2-yl)benzamide and diacids containing various amino acids (isoluecine, valine, methionine, and phenylalanine) under green conditions.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All chemicals used were of analytical reagent grade purchased from Fluka Chemical Co. (Buchs, Switzerland), Aldrich Chemical Co. (Milwaukee, WI), Riedel-deHaen AG (Seelze, Germany), and Merck (Darmstadt, Germany) unless otherwise stated. 2-Aminothiazole, 3,5-dinitrobenzoylchloride, acetone, hydrazine hydrochloride, ferric chloride, and propylene oxide from Merck were used for the synthesis of mediators. N,N′-Dimethylformamide (DMF; d = 0.94 g cm−3 at 20°C) was distilled over barium oxide under reduced pressure. Other reagents were used without further purification.

sec.title: Techniques
sec.p: Proton nuclear magnetic resonance ( 1 H NMR, 400 MHz) spectra were carried out using Bruker Avance 500 instrument (D-755 of the Roger-Gaudry, Germany) at room temperature (RT) in dimethylsulphoxide-d 6 (DMSO-d 6). Multiplicities of proton resonance were designated as singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), and multiplet (m). Fourier-transformed infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a spectrophotometer (Jasco-680, Japan). The spectra of solids were obtained using KBr pellets. The vibrational transition frequencies are reported in wavenumbers (cm−1). Band intensities are assigned as weak (w), medium (m), strong (s), and broad (br). Inherent viscosities were measured using a Cannon Fenske Routine Viscometer (Germany) at a concentration of 0.5 g dL−1 at 25°C. Specific rotations were measured by a Jasco Polarimeter (Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is performed with a STA503 win TA (BAHR GmbH,. Hilhorst, Germany) at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 ranging from 25°C to 800°C under nitrogen atmosphere. The x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the polymers were recorded using an x-ray diffractometer (Bruker, D8 Advance, Germany) with a copper target at 40 kV and 35 mA and Cu Kα λ = 1.54 Å in the range of 10–80° at a speed of 0.05° min−1. The morphology of the polymers was observed using field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM; Hitachi S-4160, Japan). The effect of ultrasonic radiation on the size of polymer particles was investigated by Misonix ultrasonic liquid processors (XL-2000 Series, USA). Ultrasound is a wave with a frequency of 2.25 × 104 Hz and power of 100 W.

sec.title: Monomer synthesis
sec.p: N, N′-(pyromellitoyl)-bis-l-α-amino acids were prepared according to our previous works. 39,40

sec.title: Catalyst preparation
sec.p: Iron oxide hydroxide catalyst was prepared according to the literature 41 : 14 g of iron (III) chloride is dissolved in 41 mL of distilled water and NaOH is added to the solution to bring the pH to 7. Then the suspension was heated to 60°C and maintained at this temperature for 12 h. After centrifugation and drying, the catalyst was redispersed and milled to a fine powder. Half an hour before the reaction to be started, the catalyst was activated by adding few drops of distilled water to develop its full catalytic activity in organic solvents. Then, it was filtered off and was washed and reused for further reductions.

sec.title: Synthesis of 3,5-diamino-N-(thiazol-2-yl)benzamide
sec.p: 3,5-Dinitro-N-(thiazol-2-yl)benzamide (3) was synthesized according to reported procedure. 42 A solution of (3) (1.47 g, 5 mmol) in methanol (25 mL) was added to iron oxide hydroxide catalyst (50 mg). Then hydrazine hydrate (70 mmol, 3 mL) was added dropwise and the reaction mixture was stirred under reflux for 14 h. At the end of reaction (monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC)), the mixture was filtered off and the resulting solid was washed with acetone. Then the filtrate was evaporated in vacuo and recrystallized from methanol to provide aforementioned compound (4).

The PAIs were prepared by the following general procedure: a mixture of aromatic diacid 5a (0.200 g, 0.45 mmol), diamine 4 (0.105 g, 0.45 mmol), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB; 0.58 g, 1.8 mmol) was ground until a powder was formed. After the mixture was completely ground, it was transferred into a 25-mL round-bottomed flask and then 0.3 mL (0.89 mmol) of triphenyl phosphite (TPP) was added to the mixture, which was heated until a homogeneous solution was formed. Then, the solution was stirred for 12 h at 120°C, and the viscous solution was precipitated in 15 mL of methanol. The brown solid was filtered off and dried to give 0.255 g (88%) of PAI6a. The other PAIs, that is, PAI6b–PAI6d, were prepared with a similar procedure.

sec.title: Characterization of diamine monomer
sec.p: A diamine monomer containing 2-amino thiazole pendant group (4) was synthesized according to the synthesis pathway shown in Figure 1. The FTIR absorptions related to the amide carbonyl group appeared at 1635 cm−1. The familiar double absorption peaks of amine functions and the amide N–H are obvious around 3385–3443 cm−1. The 1 H NMR spectrum (Figure 2) confirms the proposed structure for diamine (4). Two classic doublet peaks at 7.2 and 7.5 ppm are related to the CH thiazole aromatic ring. Both the number and the situation of peaks in 13C NMR spectra prove the presented chemical structure of diamine (4) clearly (Figure 3). There was fine agreement between calculated and found amounts of elemental analysis.

13 C NMR (125 MHz) spectrum of diamine (4) in DMSO-d 6 at RT. 13 C NMR: 13 C nuclear magnetic resonance; DMSO-d 6: dimethylsulphoxide-d 6; RT: room temperature.

sec.title: Polymer synthesis
sec.p: Optically active aromatic PA6a–PA6d were synthesized by the reaction of optically active dicarboxylic diacids 5a–5d with aromatic diamine (4) through the direct polycondensation procedure. From a technological point of view, the use of an organic solvent in large-scale production is not very genial. We decided to synthesize a series of new optically active PAIs bearing thiazole pendant groups from an equimolar mixture of diamine monomer and four different diacids derived from amino acids, including isoleucine (Ile), valine (Val), Methionine (Met), phenylalanine (Phe), and using molten TBAB as the reaction medium (Figure 4). The obtained data from the polymerization reactions of diamine (4) with four aromatic diacids in molten TBAB are listed in Table 1. This method required very small amount of IL to promote the polymerization. All the PAIs have a chiral center in their backbone, and the results showed that these PAIs are optically active with different specific rotations. Inherent viscosity values of these polymers under optimized condensations are in the range of 0.20–0.28 dL g−1 showing a moderate molecular weight. The molecular weight is not very high. This could be due to the high polar functionality in the structure of monomers. If it goes to higher molecular weight, it may not be soluble.

Synthesis and some physical properties of PAI6a–PAI6d prepared in TBAB.

sec.title: FTIR study
sec.p: The structures of these polymers were confirmed as PAIs by means of FTIR spectroscopy. All the polymers were characterized by the absorption peak for the amide N–H groups at around 3300 cm−1. Absorption of amide N–H bonds appeared at around 3310–3331 cm−1 (hydrogen band) and the peaks at 1765 and 1710 cm−1 (C=O asymmetric and symmetric, respectively, imide group), 1620 cm−1 (C=O, amide) confirm the presence of different carbonyl groups in the polymer chain. The absorption bands appeared at around 3013–3100 cm−1 and 2850–2930 cm−1 are related to the corresponding aromatic and aliphatic C–H stretching vibration, respectively. All of them exhibited strong absorptions at 1384 cm−1 and 718–720 cm−1 that show the presence of the imide heterocycle ring in these polymers.

sec.title: 1 H NMR study
sec.p: Figure 5 shows the 1 H NMR (400 MHz) spectrum of PAI6a. In the 1 H NMR spectrum of this polymer, appearances of the N–H protons of amide groups at 12.68 and 10.34 as two singlet peaks, respectively, indicate the presence of amide groups in the polymer’s side chain as well as main chain. The resonance of aromatic protons appeared in the range of 6.84–8.52 ppm. The proton of the chiral center appeared as doublet at 4.72 ppm. The resonance of the CH2 protons of PAI6a appeared multiplets at 1.563 ppm.

sec.title: Solubility of PAIs
sec.p: All the PAIs are soluble in organic polar aprotic solvents such as N-methylpyrrolidone, N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMAc), and DMF as well as polar protic solvent such as H2SO4 at RT and are insoluble in solvents such as chloroform, methylene chloride, methanol, ethanol, and water. The excellent solubility of these PAIs is appropriate to the presence of bulky side group that prevents from packing the macromolecules by hydrogen bonds between amide groups in the chain and thus facilitating the dispersion of solvent molecules among the polymer chains. The polymer solutions are very stable and no gelation, phase separation, or precipitation were observed after storage for several weeks.

sec.title: Thermal properties
sec.p: The thermal stabilities of PAI6a and PAI6b were measured by TGA. The temperatures for 5% and 10% weight loss in a nitrogen atmosphere are given in Table 2, and the thermograms are shown in Figure 6. Most of the polymers possessed high thermal stability with 5% and 10% weight loss in the range of 363–403°C. These copolymers were amorphous and had no melting points. The thermal stability of resulting polymers is due to the introduction of high rigid pyromellitoyl group into the PAI backbone. Char yield can be used as a criterion for evaluating limiting oxygen index (LOI) of the polymers in accordance with Van Krevelen and Hoftyzer equation, 43 which is LOI = 17.5 + 0.4 CR, where CR indicates char yield. Polymers had LOI values calculated based on their char yield at 800°C was higher than 32. On the basis of LOI values, such macromolecules can be classified as self-extinguishing polymers.

sec.title: Morphology investigations
sec.p: Morphology of the PAI6a and PAI6b was recorded by XRD, which is the most commonly used methods to study the structure of nanostructure materials. For PAI6a and PAI6b, it could be observed that, except one crystalline peak, there is a lack of any diffraction peak in the range of 2θ angle (Figure 7). The diffraction patterns reveal the presence of small percentage of crystalline phases when compared with the amorphous phase, which is primarily due to the bulky pendant groups. Furthermore, the amorphous nature of these polymers is also reflected in their good solubility, which is in agreement with the general rule that the solubility decreases with increasing crystallinity.

caption.p: X-Ray diffraction curves of the PAI6a and PAI6b. PAI: poly(amide-imide).

sec.p: In this study, it is worth mentioning that the FE-SEM pictures of the synthesized PAIs showed that the obtained macromolecules have nanostructured morphology (Figures 8 and 9). These figures also show that PAI6a, PAI6c and PAI6d have spherical shape, and PAI6b has a spongy morphology. In order to study the effect of ultrasound waves on the morphology of these polymers, synthesized PAIs were irradiated for 45 min in cold ethanol mixture under ultrasonic energy. Compared with the low-frequency mechanical oscillation, ultrasound energy can influence the viscoelasticity and rheology of polymer as well as size and shape of polymer particles. The effects of ultrasound on polymers can be both physical and chemical. Ultrasound irradiation of liquids can cause solely physical changes from acoustic streaming, such as rapid mixing and bulk heating. Although cavitation is not always essential for these effects, they almost constantly come with cavitation. Examples of physical changes induced by ultrasound in polymer systems include the dispersion of fillers and other constituents into base polymers, the encapsulation of inorganic particles with polymers, modification of particle size in polymer powders, and, perhaps most important, the welding and cutting of thermoplastics. 44 By comparing FE-SEM images before (Figure 8) and after (Figure 9) ultrasonic irradiation, the results showed that after sonication process, the size of PAI particles was decreased. According to these data, before sonication process, PAIs showed the spherical shapes and the particle size is around 50–90 nm, while after this process, the size of PAIs decreased and showed smaller particle in the range of 30–70 nm.

caption.p: FE-SEM of PAIs (6a–6d) before ultrasonic irradiation. FE-SEM: field emission scanning electron micrographs; PAI: poly(amide-imide).
FE-SEM micrographs of PAIs (6a–6d) after ultrasonic irradiation. FE-SEM: field emission scanning electron micrographs; PAI: poly(amide-imide).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Ultimate goal of this investigation was the synthesis of a series of thermostable and optically active aromatic PAIs that possess several advanced characteristics such as optical activity and possession of wholly aromatic backbone under green condition. This environmentally friendly green technique is a safe, fast, high yielding, economical, and simple manipulation route that avoids the usage of volatile organic solvents and catalyst. The synthesized polymers are expected to have the potential to be used as optically active packing materials in column chromatography for resolution of racemic mixtures. With XRD, it was found that all these polymers were amorphous. Morphology study of resulting polymers showed that the polymeric particles were nanosized by FE-SEM analysis. Also, the effect of ultrasonic irradiation on the size and shape of polymer nanoparticles was studied, and the results showed that the size of polymer particles was decreased after sonication process. In addition, due to the existence of amino acids in the backbone of PAIs, these polymers are anticipated to be biodegradable and therefore could be classified under environmental benign materials.
